example.text: It's nothing more than a shameless attempt to use the threat of criminal penalties to deter more doctors from providing abortion services in the first place. The other measure the GOP brought up this week was a resolution to condemn recent attacks on anti-choice facilities, but said nothing about similar attacks on women's health clinics across the US The fact that the House Republicans were willing to go to such lengths to condemn the attacks against anti-choice groups, while remaining silent about the growing violence against abortion providers, sends a very dangerous message to extremists across the country.

While this week, once again, highlighted Republicans' desire to advance their extreme agenda no matter what, I remain hopeful that there will still be opportunities to work together to get things done because I am committed, regardless of whether I'm in the minority or majority, to doing everything I can to continue advancing our priorities and help move this country forward. And I hope you will continue to share with me all of your thoughts and ideas along the way.

I'm thrilled to announce that in addition to the $13 million we secured earlier this year, I have just secured an additional $24.2 million to fund 14 more projects in our area as part of the government spending bill Congress passed today. Most of these projects will be aimed directly at helping those experiencing homelessness in our community, including $4 million to help fund the construction of 74 new apartments for low-income, single-parents in Denver's Warren Village; $4 million to help fund the purchase of the now-abandoned Clarion Hotel in North Denver and convert it into more housing for those experiencing homelessness; and $1 million for Habitat for Humanity to build several new homes in Denver's Villa Park.

Let’s be clear: The only reason we’re facing a possible default is because Republicans continue to hold our economy hostage unless we agree to their extreme agenda. The GOP created this crisis. By refusing to end it, they are threatening to do real harm to millions of Americans.

While none of these projects, alone, will solve the crisis we face overnight, they will go a long way to helping a lot of people in our area - and each project will play an important role in building a broader web of support to help those experiencing homelessness throughout the Denver area. Below you will find a full list of the 14 projects that will now be funded in our area: As always, if you have any questions about these or any other issue, please call my office at 303-844-4988, or visit my website at where you can learn more about all of the different ways my staff is available to assist you.

I’m glad to hear that President Biden will be visiting Hiroshima’s Peace Memorial Park while he’s in Japan this week. His visit will send a powerful message about the strength of our alliance and reaffirms our commitment to peace, security and denuclearization around the world.

Most of these projects will be aimed directly at helping those experiencing homelessness in our community, including $4 million to help fund the construction of 74 new apartments for low-income, single-parents in Denver's Warren Village; $4 million to help fund the purchase of the now-abandoned Clarion Hotel in North Denver and convert it into more housing for those experiencing homelessness; and $1 million for Habitat for Humanity to build several new homes in Denver's Villa Park.
